User Assignment and Resource Allocation for Hierarchical Federated Learning over Wireless Networks ††thanks: T. Zhang, K. Lam, and J. Zhao are with the Strategic Research Centre for Research in Privacy-Preserving Technologies and Systems, and the School of Computer Science and Engineering at Nanyang Technological University, Singapore. (Emails: tinghao001@e.ntu.edu.sg; kwokyan.lam@ntu.edu.sg; junzhao@ntu.edu.sg).

Tinghao Zhang, Kwok-Yan Lam, Senior Member, IEEE, Jun Zhao
Abstract

The large population of wireless users is a key driver of data-crowdsourced Machine Learning (ML). However, data privacy remains a significant concern. Federated Learning (FL) encourages data sharing in ML without requiring data to leave users’ devices but imposes heavy computation and communications overheads on mobile devices. Hierarchical FL (HFL) alleviates this problem by performing partial model aggregation at edge servers. HFL can effectively reduce energy consumption and latency through effective resource allocation and appropriate user assignment. Nevertheless, resource allocation in HFL involves optimizing multiple variables, and the objective function should consider both energy consumption and latency, making the development of resource allocation algorithms very complicated. Moreover, it is challenging to perform user assignment, which is a combinatorial optimization problem in a large search space. This article proposes a spectrum resource optimization algorithm (SROA) and a two-stage iterative algorithm (TSIA) for HFL. Given an arbitrary user assignment pattern, SROA optimizes CPU frequency, transmit power, and bandwidth to minimize system cost. TSIA aims to find a user assignment pattern that considerably reduces the total system cost. Experimental results demonstrate the superiority of the proposed HFL framework over existing studies in energy and latency reduction.

I Introduction

Machine learning (ML) has been widely used in a variety of areas such as image classification, natural language processing, and autonomous control [1]. ML usually requires a massive amount of training data to achieve satisfactory model performance. In recent years, data crowdsourcing has emerged as an important paradigm for acquiring training data needed by ML [2, 3, 4]. In particular, mobile application service providers have been deploying innovative reward schemes to incentivize mobile users to participate in data crowdsourcing. As part of the efforts to develop smart cities and promote the digital economy, many government agencies are also adopting data crowdsourcing to acquire data to fuel ML. Given the pervasive adoption of smart mobile devices, the large population of wireless mobile users plays a key role in data-crowdsourced ML. In the most straightforward manner, all participating mobile users transmit their crowdsourced data to some cloud server for centralized training, which is bottlenecked by limited bandwidth resources and privacy concerns [5]. Furthermore, there are major concerns of the users that need to be addressed to gain people’s trust and remove the hurdles in supporting data crowdsourcing [6]. These issues include cybersecurity of the central server, data privacy of the users and resource consumption on their mobile devices. In particular, battery and bandwidth consumption are of particular concern to most mobile users [7, 8, 9].

To address the problems of centralized training, a decentralized ML framework called Federated Learning (FL) is widely adopted as an approach for encouraging data sharing in ML without requiring data to leave the devices of the participants [10]. In FL, mobile users train the local model on their datasets, and the model weights are transmitted to a remote server for model aggregation. Compared with centralized training, FL provides better protection against privacy leakage as the training data are kept on mobile users [11, 12, 13]. While enhancing data privacy, however, FL requires a non-trivial amount of computation to be performed on the mobile device, hence inevitably leading to high energy consumption and depleting device batteries rapidly. Besides, uploading local models to the aggregation server consumes valuable wireless bandwidth. In addition, due to the bandwidth issues, FL needs to be designed carefully to scale up the size of data crowdsourcing, which will directly impact the model performance. FL relying on a single server for model aggregation tends to cause network congestion [14].

Recently, the deployment architecture of FL was extended to address multi-server scenarios. The novel FL framework, namely Hierarchical Federated Learning (HFL), consists of several edge servers and one cloud server. Mobile users in HFL train the models locally and then send their model weights to the corresponding edge servers for edge aggregation. After several edge iterations, the edge servers transmit the edge models to the cloud for global aggregation. HFL has great potential in alleviating communication overheads. More importantly, the cybersecurity protection of HFL can be implemented more flexibly, thus reducing the impact on accuracy and computations [15].

Despite the advantages, some issues of HFL have not been fully investigated yet. For example, the communication and computation resources should be properly allocated to mobile users. As mobile users will inevitably consume higher energy if pursuing a lower time delay, it is crucial for resource allocation to balance the tradeoff between the time delay and energy consumption. In addition, resource allocation is anticipated to jointly optimize both local resources (e.g., CPU frequency and transmit power of mobile users) and system resources (e.g., network bandwidth), as these resources have a significant impact on the energy consumption and latency of the HFL system. As a result, designing an efficient resource allocation algorithm for HFL is difficult due to its complex objective and the presence of multiple variables to be jointly optimized. Besides performing resource allocation, each mobile user will be allocated to an edge server before training. Without a feasible user assignment algorithm, some edge servers may experience prolonged latency during edge updates caused by straggling mobile users. As the cloud server conducts global aggregation only when receiving the model weights from all the edge servers, the straggling mobile users will finally deteriorate the overall latency of HFL. Moreover, if the straggling mobile users increase computation frequency to reduce the computational latency, the energy consumption to perform local update will notably rise. Therefore, user assignment plays a crucial role in reducing the energy consumption and latency of HFL. Whereas, it is hard to directly solve the user assignment problem since it is a combinatorial optimization problem with a large search space. Thus, how to carry out user assignment is another challenge of deploying HFL.

This paper proposes a spectrum resource optimization algorithm (SROA) to handle the resource allocation problem and a two-stage iterative algorithm (TSIA) to deal with the user assignment problem in HFL. The main contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

  1. 1.

    We formulate a joint communication and computation optimization problem to minimize the total system cost, which is represented as the weighted sum of the time delay and energy consumption for training the entire HFL algorithm. To address this problem, we propose a novel HFL framework that contains two key modules: SROA-based resource allocation and TSIA-based user assignment.

  2. 2.

    We propose a spectrum resource optimization algorithm (SROA) to cope with the resource allocation problem in HFL. Given a user assignment pattern, SROA aims to minimize the total system cost by optimizing the CPU frequency, average transmit power, and the bandwidth allocated to edge servers and mobile users. To this end, SROA adopts the divide-and-conquer paradigm and utilizes binary search methods to obtain the locally optimal solution to the resource allocation problem.

  3. 3.

    We propose a two-stage iterative algorithm (TSIA) for the user assignment problem. TSIA adjusts the user assignment pattern by iteratively transforming users from resource-intensive edge servers to more economical servers, thereby achieving a more balanced workload distribution. Among the patterns TSIA has explored, the user assignment pattern with the lowest total system cost is chosen as the solution to the user assignment problem.

  4. 4.

    We conduct extensive numerical experiments to evaluate the proposed methods. Given a user assignment pattern, SROA achieves a lower total system cost than the existing resource allocation methods. TSIA outperforms the state-of-the-art user assignment methods in reducing the total system cost and convergence speed. Moreover, the proposed HFL framework achieves a lower total system cost than traditional FL.

The rest of the paper is organized as follows. The related work is listed in Section II. The system model and problem formulation are formulated in Section III. The SROA algorithm is described in Section IV. The TSIA algorithm is explained in Section V. Experimental results are analyzed in Section VI followed by the conclusion in Section VII.

II Related Work

Federated Learning has become a mainstream topic in the field of machine learning. Some existing researches focus on defense algorithms such as differential privacy [16, 17, 18], secure multi-party computation [19, 20, 21], and homomorphic encryption [22, 23, 24], to improve user security in FL. However, such defences will either drop the accuracy or incur additional computation overheads [25, 26, 27]. In contrast, HFL allows the defences to be deployed more flexibly. For example, it is unnecessary to implement secure aggregation for the upper layers of HFL as the cloud only processes the edge models and has no access to the users’ update [15].

Some researchers investigate resource allocation problems to alleviate the communication and computation overheads in FL. For example, [28] proposes a joint user scheduling and bandwidth allocation method to pursue better learning performance of FL. [29] designs a joint power allocation and scheduling algorithm to optimize the convergence speed of FL. [30] minimizes the time delay for training the entire FL algorithm by introducing a joint resource allocation and user scheduling scheme. [31] balances the tradeoff between local computation delay and wireless transmission delay to minimize the time delay of FL. [32] aims to minimize the time delay by optimizing bandwidth allocation. Nevertheless, [28, 29, 30, 31, 32] do not optimize the energy consumption in FL. [33] conducts bandwidth allocation based on the channel conditions and computation capacities. However, the time delay is not optimized in [33]. [34] proposes Federated Learning over wireless networks problem (FEDL) to balance the energy consumption and time delay of training FL. In traditional FL, however, the mobile users upload the model weights to a single remote server in these works, which still faces high communication overheads. HFL can mitigate the network congestion by partially transferring the aggregation processes to multiple edge servers [35].

In terms of HFL, [36] proposes a basic HFL framework and theoretically analyzes the convergence rate of HFL. [15] analyzes the potential of HFL for addressing privacy issues in traditional FL. [37] presents an HFL framework that adopts a local-area network and a wide-area network to accelerate the training process and alleviate network traffic. However, resource allocation and user assignment are not discussed in the aforementioned studies. [38] proposes a user assignment algorithm for HFL to speed up the convergence speed of HFL on the non-IID datasets. Nevertheless, [38] does not consider the energy consumption and latency of HFL. [35] proposes HFEL that solves both jointly solve the resource allocation and user assignment problems. [39] proposes a joint bandwidth allocation and user assignment framework to improve the time delay and learning performance of training HFL. Our proposed method is compared with [35] and [39] and exhibits the superior performance.

III System Model

A typical HFL framework includes N𝑁N users indexed by 𝒩={1,2,…,N}𝒩12…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\left\{1,2,...,N\right\}, M𝑀M edge servers indexed by ℳ={1,2,…,M}ℳ12…𝑀\mathcal{M}=\left\{1,2,...,M\right\}, and a cloud server. Each mobile user n𝑛n has a local dataset 𝒟nsubscript𝒟𝑛\mathcal{D}_{n} with Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} data samples. The models trained on the local devices are called local models, while the models aggregated at the edge and cloud are called edge models and global models, respectively.

III-A HFL training

At the i𝑖i-th global iteration, the training process of HFL contains three steps: local training, edge aggregation, and global aggregation.

1) Local Training: We define 𝒘ni,k,lsuperscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑖𝑘𝑙\bm{w}_{n}^{i,k,l} as the model parameters of local model n𝑛n. Local training adopts a gradient descent algorithm to update the local models as follows:

𝒘ni,k,l+1=𝒘ni,k,l−β​∇Fn​(𝒘ni,k,l),superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑖𝑘𝑙1superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑖𝑘𝑙𝛽∇subscript𝐹𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑖𝑘𝑙\bm{w}_{n}^{i,k,l+1}=\bm{w}_{n}^{i,k,l}-\beta\nabla F_{n}(\bm{w}_{n}^{i,k,l}), (1)

where Fn​(𝒘ni,k,l)subscript𝐹𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑖𝑘𝑙F_{n}(\bm{w}_{n}^{i,k,l}) is the loss function of local model n𝑛n at the k𝑘k-th edge iteration of the i𝑖i-th global iteration, and β𝛽\beta is the learning rate. Local training ends when achieving the maximum number of local iterations L𝐿L.

2) Edge Aggregation: To carry out edge aggregation, the mobile users upload their model weights to the edge servers. We define Ψ=[𝒩m|m∈ℳ]Ψdelimited-[]conditionalsubscript𝒩𝑚𝑚ℳ\Psi=\left[\mathcal{N}_{m}\big{|}m\in\mathcal{M}\right] as an user assignment pattern, where 𝒩m​(m=1,…,M)subscript𝒩𝑚𝑚1…𝑀\mathcal{N}_{m}\ (m=1,...,M) is the set of mobile users assigned to edge server m𝑚m. Each edge conducts aggregation by averaging the model weights:

𝒘mi,k+1=∑n∈𝒩mDn​𝒘ni,k,LD𝒩m,superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝑖𝑘1subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝐷𝑛superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑛𝑖𝑘𝐿subscript𝐷subscript𝒩𝑚\bm{w}_{m}^{i,k+1}=\frac{\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}D_{n}\bm{w}_{n}^{i,k,L}}{D_{\mathcal{N}_{m}}}, (2)

where D𝒩m=∑n∈𝒩mDnsubscript𝐷subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝐷𝑛D_{\mathcal{N}_{m}}=\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}D_{n}. The edge will transmit the averaged model weights back to the mobile users. Local training and edge aggregation are repeated until the maximum edge iteration number K𝐾K is achieved.

3) Global Aggregation: In this phase, the edge servers upload the weights to the cloud server. The cloud server receives the model weights from the edges and averages them:

𝒘i+1=∑m=1MD𝒩m​𝒘mi,KD,superscript𝒘𝑖1superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐷subscript𝒩𝑚superscriptsubscript𝒘𝑚𝑖𝐾𝐷\bm{w}^{i+1}=\frac{\sum_{m=1}^{M}D_{\mathcal{N}_{m}}\bm{w}_{m}^{i,K}}{D}, (3)

where D=∑m=1MD𝒩m𝐷superscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐷subscript𝒩𝑚D=\sum_{m=1}^{M}D_{\mathcal{N}_{m}}. The cloud server broadcasts the global model to the scheduled users through the edge servers. Algorithm 1 explains the training process of HFL at the i𝑖i-th global iteration. Note that one global iteration contains K𝐾K edge iterations (i.e., L×K𝐿𝐾L\times K local iterations). The convergence proof of the HFL framework is provided in our online file [40] due to space limitation.

III-B Energy consumption and time delay in HFL

The energy consumption and time delay of HFL can be obtained by analyzing the computation and transmission processes.

We define cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n} as the number of CPU cycles for user n𝑛n to compute one data sample. Let fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} be the CPU frequency of n𝑛n. We assume that all data samples have the same size. At each edge iteration, the energy consumption Encmpsuperscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cmpE_{n}^{\text{cmp}} and time delay Tncmpsuperscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛cmpT_{n}^{\text{cmp}} for user n𝑛n to process Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} data samples are:

Tncmp=L​cn​Dnfn,superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛cmp𝐿subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛T_{n}^{\text{cmp}}=\frac{Lc_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}}, (4)
Encmp=α2​L​fn2​cn​Dn,superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cmp𝛼2𝐿superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛2subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛E_{n}^{\text{cmp}}=\frac{\alpha}{2}Lf_{n}^{2}c_{n}D_{n}, (5)

where L𝐿L is the maximum number of local iterations, and α2𝛼2\frac{\alpha}{2} denotes the effective capacitance coefficient of the user’s computing chipset.

After L𝐿L local iterations, the mobile users will transmit the model weights to the corresponding edge server. In this work, we adopt a frequency-division multiple access (FDMA) protocol for data transmission. The achievable transmission rate of user n𝑛n is:

rn=bn​log2​(1+gnm​pnN0​bn),subscript𝑟𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛subscriptlog21superscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚subscript𝑝𝑛subscript𝑁0subscript𝑏𝑛r_{n}=b_{n}\text{log}_{2}(1+\frac{g_{n}^{m}p_{n}}{N_{0}b_{n}}), (6)

where bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} is the bandwidth allocated to user n𝑛n, gnmsuperscriptsubscript𝑔𝑛𝑚g_{n}^{m} is the channel gain between the mobile user n𝑛n and edge server m𝑚m, N0subscript𝑁0N_{0} is background noise, and pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} is the transmit power. At each edge iteration, the energy consumption Encomsubscriptsuperscript𝐸com𝑛E^{\text{com}}_{n} and time delay Tncomsubscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛T^{\text{com}}_{n} for user n𝑛n to transmit the model weights to the edge are:

Tncom=srn,subscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛𝑠subscript𝑟𝑛T^{\text{com}}_{n}=\frac{s}{r_{n}}, (7)
Encom=pn​Tncom,subscriptsuperscript𝐸com𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛E^{\text{com}}_{n}=p_{n}T^{\text{com}}_{n}, (8)

where s𝑠s denotes the size of the HFL model. Note that the time delay and energy consumption for mobile users to download the aggregated model weights are neglected compared with the upload mode. Based on the above discussion, the energy consumption Emsubscript𝐸𝑚E_{m} and time delay Tmsubscript𝑇𝑚T_{m} of edge server m𝑚m after K𝐾K edge iterations are:

Tm=K​maxn∈𝒩m⁡(Tncmp+Tncom).subscript𝑇𝑚𝐾subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑇𝑛cmpsubscriptsuperscript𝑇com𝑛T_{m}=K\max_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}\left(T_{n}^{\text{cmp}}+T^{\text{com}}_{n}\right). (9)
Em=K​∑n∈𝒩m(Encmp+Encom).subscript𝐸𝑚𝐾subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐸𝑛cmpsubscriptsuperscript𝐸com𝑛E_{m}=K\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}(E_{n}^{\text{cmp}}+E^{\text{com}}_{n}). (10)

The aggregated model weights at each edge server are uploaded to the cloud server after K𝐾K edge iterations. The energy consumption Emcloudsubscriptsuperscript𝐸cloud𝑚E^{\text{cloud}}_{m} and time delay Tmcloudsubscriptsuperscript𝑇cloud𝑚T^{\text{cloud}}_{m} for edge server m𝑚m to upload the model weights to the cloud server are derived as:

Tmcloud=srm,subscriptsuperscript𝑇cloud𝑚𝑠subscript𝑟𝑚T^{\text{cloud}}_{m}=\frac{s}{r_{m}}, (11)
Emcloud=pm​Tmcloud,subscriptsuperscript𝐸cloud𝑚subscript𝑝𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑇cloud𝑚E^{\text{cloud}}_{m}=p_{m}T^{\text{cloud}}_{m}, (12)

where smsubscript𝑠𝑚s_{m} is the model size at edge server m𝑚m, rmsubscript𝑟𝑚r_{m} and pmsubscript𝑝𝑚p_{m} are the transmission rate and the average transmit power of edge server m𝑚m for model uploading, respectively.

The aggregation time at the edge and cloud servers is neglected as the time is much smaller than the time delay on the mobile users. As HFL cannot conduct global aggregation until the cloud server receives the model weights from all the edge servers, the time delay of HFL is determined by the slowest edge. Therefore, we have the following equations:

T=maxm∈ℳ⁡(Tmcloud+Tm),Tsum=I⋅T,formulae-sequence𝑇subscript𝑚ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝑇cloud𝑚subscript𝑇𝑚subscript𝑇sum⋅𝐼𝑇T=\max_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\left(T^{\text{cloud}}_{m}+T_{m}\right),T_{\text{sum}}=I\cdot T, (13)
E=∑m∈ℳ(Emcloud+Em),Esum=I⋅E,formulae-sequence𝐸subscript𝑚ℳsubscriptsuperscript𝐸cloud𝑚subscript𝐸𝑚subscript𝐸sum⋅𝐼𝐸E=\sum_{m\in\mathcal{M}}(E^{\text{cloud}}_{m}+E_{m}),E_{\text{sum}}=I\cdot E, (14)

where I𝐼I is the number of global iterations, T𝑇T and E𝐸E are the time delay and energy consumption of HFL at each global iteration, respectively. Tsumsubscript𝑇sumT_{\text{sum}} and Esumsubscript𝐸sumE_{\text{sum}} are the time delay and energy consumption of training the entire HFL algorithm, respectively.

III-C Problem formulation

In this paper, the optimization problem is formulated to balance the tradeoff between the energy cost and the time delay:

s.t.∑n∈𝒩mbn≤Bm,∀m∈ℳ,formulae-sequences.t.subscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝐵𝑚for-all𝑚ℳ\displaystyle\text{s.t.}\quad\sum_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}b_{n}\leq B_{m},\forall m\in\mathcal{M}, (15a)

0≤fn≤fnmax,∀n∈𝒩,formulae-sequence0subscript𝑓𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓max𝑛for-all𝑛𝒩\displaystyle\quad\quad 0\leq f_{n}\leq f^{\text{max}}_{n},\quad\forall n\in\mathcal{N}, (15c)

B𝐵B represents the total bandwidth resources for all the edge servers, and Bmsubscript𝐵𝑚B_{m} represents the bandwidth of edge server m𝑚m. fnmaxsubscriptsuperscript𝑓max𝑛f^{\text{max}}_{n} and pnmaxsubscriptsuperscript𝑝max𝑛p^{\text{max}}_{n} represent the maximum CPU frequency and maximum average transmit power of user n𝑛n, respectively. λ𝜆\lambda is an importance weighting indicator. (15a) and (15b) denote the bandwidth constraints of the mobile users and edge servers, respectively. (15c) and (15d) denote the constraints for the CPU frequency and the transmission power, respectively. (15e) ensures each mobile user only communicates with one edge server. (15f) indicates that all the mobile users participate in the training process.

Problem (15) merges combinatorial optimization (i.e., the optimization of ΨΨ\Psi) with multi-variable optimization (i.e., the optimization of B,b,fBbf\emph{{B}},\emph{{b}},\emph{{f}}, and p). Therefore, it is intractable to directly obtain the global optimum of problem (15). In this paper, we decompose problem (15) into a resource allocation problem and a user assignment problem and propose a novel HFL framework as shown in Fig. 1 to attain the locally optimal solution to problem (15). Specifically, given a known user assignment pattern ΨΨ\Psi, {(Bm,bn,fn,pn)|n∈𝒩,m∈ℳ}conditional-setsubscript𝐵𝑚subscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛subscript𝑝𝑛formulae-sequence𝑛𝒩𝑚ℳ\left\{(B_{m},b_{n},f_{n},p_{n})\big{|}n\in\mathcal{N},m\in\mathcal{M}\right\} as well as the objective value R𝑅R can be obtained by a spectrum resource optimization algorithm (SROA). With SROA, a two-stage iterative algorithm (TSIA) is designed to find the optimal user assignment pattern Ψ∗superscriptΨ∗\Psi^{\ast}. After performing SROA and TSIA, the proposed framework starts to train the HFL model based on Algorithm 1.

IV Spectrum Resource Optimization Algorithm

We introduce the spectrum resource optimization algorithm (SROA) method before the user assignment method as the proposed user assignment method in this paper relies on SROA. Given ΨΨ\Psi, SROA aims to minimize the weighted sum of time delay and energy consumption for training the entire HFL algorithm. Based on (4)-(15), the optimization problem is formulated as follows:

Obtaining the globally optimal solution for problem (16) poses significant challenges as multiple variables are required to be optimized in problem (16). Besides, the objective function (16) involves a double summation (i.e., ∑m∈ℳ∑n∈𝒩msubscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚\sum\limits_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\sum\limits_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}) and a double maximization (i.e., maxm∈ℳ⁡maxn∈𝒩msubscript𝑚ℳsubscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚\max\limits_{m\in\mathcal{M}}\max\limits_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}), thus further complicating problem (16). To simplify the optimization problem, we introduce four variables ψn,msubscript𝜓𝑛𝑚\psi_{n,m}, hnsubscriptℎ𝑛h_{n}, δnsubscript𝛿𝑛\delta_{n}, and t𝑡t to rewrite problem (16) as follows:

In addition, the bandwidth constraints (16a) and (16b) are merged into a single constraint (17a). Consequently, the resource allocation problem between the mobile users and multiple edge servers is transformed into a resource allocation problem between the mobile users and a single server with a total bandwidth resource of B𝐵B, which facilitates the optimization procedure. Note that after solving problem (17), Bmsubscript𝐵𝑚B_{m} can be obtained by ∑n∈𝒩mbnsubscript𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚subscript𝑏𝑛\sum\limits_{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}b_{n}.

To solve problem (17), SROA sets t𝑡t to a fixed value, and the optimal solutions of b,f, and pbf and p\emph{{b}},\emph{{f}},\text{ and }\emph{{p}} under the fixed t𝑡t are obtained. Next, SROA adopts a binary search algorithm to find the optimal t∗superscript𝑡∗t^{\ast} for the problem (17). SROA iteratively performs the above two steps and finally converges to a locally optimal solution (b∗,f∗,p∗)superscriptb∗superscriptf∗superscriptp∗(\emph{{b}}^{\ast},\emph{{f}}^{\ast},\emph{{p}}^{\ast}).

Given a fixed t𝑡t, the optimization goal of problem (17) becomes minimizing the energy consumption. In this case, we take two steps to obtain the optimal p,b,and fpband f\emph{{p}},\emph{{b}},\text{and }\emph{{f}}. Firstly, we design a binary search algorithm to obtain the optimal b,and fband f\emph{{b}},\text{and }\emph{{f}} with fixed (t,p)𝑡p(t,\emph{{p}}). Secondly, we propose another binary search algorithm to find the optimal p.

For the first step, the optimization problem (17) is reformulated as follows:

On the one hand, given fixed (p,tp𝑡\emph{{p}},t), the energy consumption in (21) becomes smaller with the increasing of bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} and the decreasing of fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}. On the other hand, it can be seen from (21a) that reducing fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} increases bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}. Therefore, the key idea for solving (21) is to minimize fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} while satisfying the constraint (21b). To this end, we provide Lemma 1 to facilitate the optimization. With Lemma 1, we propose a binary search method to optimize (𝒃,𝒇)𝒃𝒇(\bm{b},\bm{f}) as shown in Algorithm 2. In Algorithm 2, ε0subscript𝜀0\varepsilon_{0} is the tolerance of the algorithm. The upper bound of fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} is initialized as fnmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛maxf_{n}^{\text{max}}, while the lower bound is derived based on Lemma 1. In each iteration, fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} is updated as the average of its upper and lower bounds. In Line 4, the bisection method is employed using (21a) to calculate bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} with the known fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} since bn​log2⁡(1+Gnbn)subscript𝑏𝑛subscript21subscript𝐺𝑛subscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}\log_{2}(1+\frac{G_{n}}{b_{n}}) is a monotonically increasing function with respect to bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}. If the sum of bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} (i.e., bsumsubscript𝑏sumb_{\text{sum}}) is lower than B𝐵B, it indicates that HFL can achieve the time delay t𝑡t while preserving bandwidth resources of (B−bsum)𝐵subscript𝑏sum(B-b_{\text{sum}}). In such cases, fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} can be further reduced to minimize energy consumption. Conversely, if bsumsubscript𝑏sumb_{\text{sum}} exceeds B𝐵B, fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n} is increased. Algorithm 2 reaches convergence when the maximum value of fnup−fnlowfnupsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛upsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛lowsuperscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛up\frac{f_{n}^{\text{up}}-f_{n}^{\text{low}}}{f_{n}^{\text{up}}} becomes smaller than the tolerance ε0subscript𝜀0\varepsilon_{0}.

For the second step, we can investigate how to optimize p given the fixed (𝒃,𝒇,t)𝒃𝒇𝑡(\bm{b},\bm{f},t). The optimization problem (17) is rewritten as follows:

There is a positive correlation between p and objective function (22). Besides, reducing p increases f and b given the fixed t𝑡t according to (17d). Therefore, Algorithm 3 is proposed as a binary search method to find the optimal p. Firstly, Algorithm 3 initializes the upper and lower bounds of pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} according to pnmaxsuperscriptsubscript𝑝𝑛maxp_{n}^{\text{max}} and Lemma 2, respectively. Next, p is set to be the average of its upper and lower bounds. Then, (b,f)bf(\emph{{b}},\emph{{f}}) is obtained using Algorithm 2. Finally, pnupsubscriptsuperscript𝑝up𝑛p^{\text{up}}_{n} will be reduced if bsumsubscript𝑏sumb_{\text{sum}} is smaller than B𝐵B, otherwise pnlowsubscriptsuperscript𝑝low𝑛p^{\text{low}}_{n} is increased. The iteration stops when the tolerance ε1subscript𝜀1\varepsilon_{1} is met.

The lower bound of pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} is max⁡(0,ζ​(2γη−1))0𝜁superscript2𝛾𝜂1\max(0,\zeta(2^{\frac{\gamma}{\eta}}-1)), where γ=I​K​sbmax𝛾𝐼𝐾𝑠subscript𝑏max\gamma=\frac{IKs}{b_{\text{max}}}, η=t−δn−I​K​L​cn​Dnfnmax𝜂𝑡subscript𝛿𝑛𝐼𝐾𝐿subscript𝑐𝑛subscript𝐷𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑓𝑛max\eta=t-\delta_{n}-\frac{IKLc_{n}D_{n}}{f_{n}^{\text{max}}}, and ζ=N0​bmaxhn𝜁subscript𝑁0subscript𝑏maxsubscriptℎ𝑛\zeta=\frac{N_{0}b_{\text{max}}}{h_{n}}.

See Appendix B. ∎

IV-B Binary search algorithm for obtaining t∗superscript𝑡∗t^{\ast}

A binary search algorithm is employed to obtain the optimal t∗superscript𝑡∗t^{\ast} as shown in Algorithm 4. To begin with, the upper and lower bounds of t𝑡t are set as a large enough number and a small enough number, respectively. The optimal objective value R∗superscript𝑅∗R^{\ast} is initialized as +∞+\infty. At each iteration, t𝑡t is set as the average of its upper and lower bounds. Given t𝑡t, (b,f,p)bfp(\emph{{b}},\emph{{f}},\emph{{p}}) is derived via Algorithms 2 and Algorithm 3, and the objective value (16) is obtained with the derived (b,f,p)bfp(\emph{{b}},\emph{{f}},\emph{{p}}). t𝑡t will be reduced if a smaller R𝑅R is obtained, and vice versa. Note that the sum of bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} (i.e. bsumsubscript𝑏sumb_{\text{sum}}) can be larger than B𝐵B if t𝑡t becomes too small. Therefore, at Lines 5−-8 of Algorithm 4, we calculate bsumsubscript𝑏sumb_{\text{sum}} after carrying out Algorithm 2 and 3, and t𝑡t will be increased if bsum>Bsubscript𝑏sum𝐵b_{\text{sum}}>B. The solutions of (16) (i.e., B∗,b∗,f∗,p∗superscriptB∗superscriptb∗superscriptf∗superscriptp∗\emph{{B}}^{\ast},\emph{{b}}^{\ast},\emph{{f}}^{\ast},\emph{{p}}^{\ast}) can be obtained after t∗superscript𝑡∗t^{\ast} is found.

IV-C Complexity analysis

To begin with, the complexity of Algorithm 2 is 𝒪​(N2​log2⁡(1ε0)​log2⁡(1ε3))𝒪superscript𝑁2subscript21subscript𝜀0subscript21subscript𝜀3\mathcal{O}\left(N^{2}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}\right)}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{3}}\right)}\right), where ε3subscript𝜀3\varepsilon_{3} is the tolerance for calculating bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n} at Line 5 via the bisection method. Algorithm 3 involves complexity 𝒪​(N3​log2⁡(1ε0)​log2⁡(1ε1)​log2⁡(1ε3))𝒪superscript𝑁3subscript21subscript𝜀0subscript21subscript𝜀1subscript21subscript𝜀3\mathcal{O}\Big{(}N^{3}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}\right)}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{1}}\right)}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{3}}\right)}\Big{)}. As a result, the complexity of Algorithm 4 is 𝒪​(N3​log2⁡(1ε0)​log2⁡(1ε1)​log2⁡(1ε2)​log2⁡(1ε3))𝒪superscript𝑁3subscript21subscript𝜀0subscript21subscript𝜀1subscript21subscript𝜀2subscript21subscript𝜀3\mathcal{O}\Big{(}N^{3}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{0}}\right)}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{1}}\right)}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{2}}\right)}\log_{2}{\left(\frac{1}{\varepsilon_{3}}\right)}\Big{)}. Algorithms 2−-4 are all established by binary search algorithms. Therefore, Algorithm 4 will finally converge to a stable point and derive a locally optimal solution. According to the experimental results in Section VI-B, the derived solution of Algorithm 4 outperforms existing baselines.

V User Assignment Optimization via a Two-stage Iterative Algorithm

Below we first present the preliminaries of the two-stage iterative algorithm (TSIA) in Section V-A, and then explain TSIA details in Section V-B.

V-A Preliminaries of TSIA

Before elaborating TSIA, we introduce several important definitions. First of all, we define Rmsubscript𝑅𝑚R_{m} as the weighted sum of the energy consumption and time delay of edge server m𝑚m:

Rm=(Emcloud+Em)+λ​(Tmcloud+Tm).subscript𝑅𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝐸cloud𝑚subscript𝐸𝑚𝜆subscriptsuperscript𝑇cloud𝑚subscript𝑇𝑚R_{m}=(E^{\text{cloud}}_{m}+E_{m})+\lambda\left(T^{\text{cloud}}_{m}+T_{m}\right).\vspace{3pt} (23)

Then, we define costly server, economic server, costly user, and economic user. According to Definition 1, the costly and economic servers are the edge servers with the highest and the lowest Rmsubscript𝑅𝑚R_{m}, respectively. According to Definition 2, for edge server m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M}, the user that utilizes the most bandwidth resources of the edge server is regarded as the costly user, while the user allocated the least bandwidth is the economic user. Generally, each edge server has only one costly user and one economic user.

Definition 1.

In TSIA, the costly edge m+superscript𝑚m^{+} and economic edge m−superscript𝑚m^{-} are defined as

m+=argmaxm∈ℳ​(Rm)superscript𝑚𝑚ℳargmaxsubscript𝑅𝑚\displaystyle m^{+}=\underset{m\in\mathcal{M}}{\emph{argmax}}(R_{m}) (24)
m−=argminm∈ℳ​(Rm)superscript𝑚𝑚ℳargminsubscript𝑅𝑚\displaystyle m^{-}=\underset{m\in\mathcal{M}}{\emph{argmin}}(R_{m}) (25)
Definition 2.

In TSIA, the costly user nm+superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m}^{+} and economic user nm−superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m}^{-} of edge server m∈ℳ𝑚ℳm\in\mathcal{M} are defined as

nm+=argmaxn∈𝒩m​(bn)superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚argmaxsubscript𝑏𝑛\displaystyle n_{m}^{+}=\underset{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}{\emph{argmax}}(b_{n}) (26)
nm−=argminn∈𝒩m​(bn)superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚𝑛subscript𝒩𝑚argminsubscript𝑏𝑛\displaystyle n_{m}^{-}=\underset{n\in\mathcal{N}_{m}}{\emph{argmin}}(b_{n}) (27)

V-B Details of TSIA

The core idea of TSIA is to bridge the performance gap between the costly server and the economic server by transferring the user from the costly server to the economic server. The costly user will be transferred at the first stage, while the second stage aims to transfer the economic user. The mechanism of TSIA is straightforward. When the costly user nm+superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m}^{+} is transferred from edge server m𝑚m to other servers, edge server m𝑚m regains large amounts of bandwidth. When SROA is conducted before and after such a transfer, the results of SROA vary noticeably. In contrast, the economic user nm−superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m}^{-} does not consume many bandwidth resources of edge server m𝑚m. The transfer of nm−superscriptsubscript𝑛𝑚n_{m}^{-} can be viewed as a fine-tuning process as it has a minor impact on the total system cost. TSIA results in a balanced user assignment pattern that significantly reduces the objective value (15).

Algorithm 5 describes the implementation details of TSIA. We define ΨqsubscriptΨ𝑞\Psi_{q} (q∈ℤ+𝑞superscriptℤq\in\mathbb{Z}^{+}) as the user assignment pattern at the q𝑞q-th assigning step. In the first stage of TSIA (i.e., s​t​a​g​e=1𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑔𝑒1stage=1), the user assignment pattern ΨqsubscriptΨ𝑞\Psi_{q} and Ψ∗superscriptΨ∗\Psi^{\ast} are initialized based on geography distance (Line 5). Then, SROA is carried out given the initial user assignment pattern to initialize the optimal objective value R∗superscript𝑅∗R^{\ast} (Lines 6-7). Next, TSIA iteratively identify the costly server m+superscript𝑚m^{+}, economic server m−superscript𝑚m^{-}, and the costly user of the costly server (i.e., nm++subscriptsuperscript𝑛superscript𝑚n^{+}_{m^{+}}) based on Definition 1 and 2; the costly user nm++subscriptsuperscript𝑛superscript𝑚n^{+}_{m^{+}} is transmitted to edge server m−superscript𝑚m^{-} (Lines 12-14). The second stage (i.e., s​t​a​g​e=2𝑠𝑡𝑎𝑔𝑒2stage=2) shares many same steps with the first stage. The differences are that the second stage initializes the user assignment pattern using the pattern derived in the first stage (Line 9), and the economic user nm+−subscriptsuperscript𝑛superscript𝑚n^{-}_{m^{+}} is transferred from the costly server m+superscript𝑚m^{+} to the economic server m−superscript𝑚m^{-} (Line 16).

Remark 1.

TSIA is a deterministic policy. Specifically, given ΨqsubscriptΨ𝑞\Psi_{q}, the result of Algorithm 4, the determination of {m+,m−,nm+,nm−}superscript𝑚superscript𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑛𝑚\left\{m^{+},m^{-},n^{+}_{m},n^{-}_{m}\right\}, and the action taken by TSIA (Line 14 or Line 16 in Algorithm 5) are all deterministic. Therefore, with a fixed ΨqsubscriptΨ𝑞\Psi_{q}, TSIA always derives the same Ψq+1subscriptΨ𝑞1\Psi_{q+1}.

We propose Remark 1 to facilitate the convergence justification of TSIA. In addition to Remark 1, the number of combinations of user assignment patterns is MNsuperscript𝑀𝑁M^{N} given the numbers of mobile users N𝑁N and edge servers M𝑀M. As a result, if TSIA continues assigning the mobile users after MNsuperscript𝑀𝑁M^{N} steps, there must exist one unique assignment pattern Ψq(q∈ℤ+\Psi_{q}(q\in\mathbb{Z}^{+} and q∈[1,MN])q\in[1,M^{N}]) that satisfies ΨMN+1=ΨqsubscriptΨsuperscript𝑀𝑁1subscriptΨ𝑞\Psi_{M^{N}+1}=\Psi_{q}, which indicates the assigning pattern returns to the q𝑞q-th assigning step. Theoretically, the complexity of TSIA is 𝒪​(MN)𝒪superscript𝑀𝑁\mathcal{O}(M^{N}). Empirically, however, TSIA requires much fewer assigning iterations to reach convergence according to Fig. 6. For example, given N=50𝑁50N=50 and M=5𝑀5M=5, the assigning iterations for HFL to converge roughly ranges from 20 to 50, which is notably lower than 550superscript5505^{50}.

VI Performance Evaluation

VI-A Experimental setup

We consider N=50𝑁50N=50 mobile users and M=5𝑀5M=5 edge users randomly distributed in a square of side 500 m, and the centre of the square is the cloud server. The total bandwidth resources of the edge servers are randomly distributed in [10,1000]​KHz101000KHz[10,1000]\ \text{KHz}. The path loss model is 128.1+37.6​log10⁡d128.137.6subscript10𝑑128.1+37.6\log_{10}d(km), and the standard deviation of shadow fading is 888dB. The power spectrum density of the additive Gaussian noise is N0=−174subscript𝑁0174N_{0}=-174 dBm/MHz.

We set an equal maximum CPU frequency f1max=…=fNmax=5​GHzsubscriptsuperscript𝑓max1…subscriptsuperscript𝑓max𝑁5GHzf^{\text{max}}_{1}=...=f^{\text{max}}_{N}=5\ \text{GHz} and an equal maximum transmit power p1max=…=pNmax=23​dBmsubscriptsuperscript𝑝max1…subscriptsuperscript𝑝max𝑁23dBmp^{\text{max}}_{1}=...=p^{\text{max}}_{N}=23\ \text{dBm}. cn​(n∈𝒩)subscript𝑐𝑛𝑛𝒩c_{n}\ (n\in\mathcal{N}) is randomly distributed in [1,10]×104110superscript104[1,10]\times 10^{4} cycles/sample. The effective capacitance coefficient α=2×10−28𝛼2superscript1028\alpha=2\times 10^{-28}. The maximum local iteration L𝐿L and maximum edge iteration K𝐾K are both 5 in this paper. The dataset for training HFL and the network structure of the HFL model are provided as follows.

FashionMNIST: FashionMNIST [41] is a dataset that contains Zalando’s article images. It consists of 60000 training samples and 10000 testing samples. Each data sample is a 28×28282828\times 28 grey-scale image. There are a total of 10 classes in FashionMNIST. The HFL model used for training FashionMNIST consists of two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers, and the output dimension of the first convolution layer and the second convolution layer are 10 and 12, respectively. The convolution layers are followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling. The output of the last pooling layer is flattened and fed into a linear layer. The size of the local dataset Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} is randomly distributed in [1000,1400]10001400[1000,1400]. The size of the model weights s=446​KB𝑠446KBs=446\ \text{KB}.

CIFAR-10: CIFAR-10 [42] is a ten-class dataset that contains 60000 32×32323232\times 32 color images. Each class has 5000 training images and 1000 testing images. The HFL model has two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers and two linear layers. The output channels of the two convolution layers are 10 and 20, respectively. Each convolution layer is followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling. The output of the last pooling layer is connected with two linear layers. The size of the local dataset Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} is randomly distributed in [800,1200]8001200[800,1200]. The size of the model weights s=523​KB𝑠523KBs=523\ \text{KB}.

ImageNette: ImageNette [43] is formulated by selecting ten easily classified classes from ImageNet [44]. It includes 9469 training samples and 3925 testing samples. We resize the images to 32×32323232\times 32. The HFL model contains two 5×5555\times 5 convolution layers and two linear layers. The output channels of the two convolution layers are 15 and 28, respectively. The convolution layers are followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling. The output dimensions of the linear layers are 300 and 10, respectively. The size of the local dataset Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} is randomly distributed in [150,220]150220[150,220]. The size of the model weights s=881​KB𝑠881KBs=881\ \text{KB}.

Among these datasets, the images in FashionMNIST are the simplest and easiest to be identified, while ImageNette has an incremental level of difficulty over FashionMNIST and CIFAR-10.

VI-B Results of resource optimization methods

We compare the proposed SROA with several state-of-art baselines. Although SROA is primarily designed for FDMA systems, its applicability can be readily extended to alternative communication schemes such as Orthogonal Frequency Division Multiple Access (OFDMA). Therefore, we assess the performance of SROA in both FDMA and OFDMA scenarios. For the baselines in the FDMA scheme, JDSRA [32] is used for comparison. For the baselines in the OFDMA scheme, ERA [33] and the resource allocation method in JUARA [39] are used as the baseline methods. In addition, FEDL [34] and the resource allocation method in HFEL [35] can be applied for both FDMA scheme and OFDMA scheme. The experiments are conducted under Dn∈[150,220]subscript𝐷𝑛150220D_{n}\in[150,220], s=881​KB𝑠881KBs=881\ \text{KB}, I=80𝐼80I=80, and the mobile users are simply assigned to the edge server closest to their location.

Figure 2 illustrates the objective value (15) obtained through various resource allocation methods. In our analysis, we assign equal importance weights (λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1) to our proposed method (SROA), FEDL, and HFEL, indicating an equal emphasis on time delay and energy cost. From the results depicted in Figure 2, it is evident that SROA achieves the lowest objective value in both the FDMA and OFDMA schemes. This outcome can be attributed to the comprehensive nature of SROA, which considers multiple factors such as time delay and energy consumption, and optimizes the allocation of bandwidth, CPU frequency, and average transmit power in a joint manner. In contrast, existing baselines either optimize fewer parameters or considers only one perspective (either energy consumption or time delay). Figure 3 displays the objective value (15) obtained through different resource allocation methods for various values of λ𝜆\lambda. The range of λ𝜆\lambda spans from 10−3superscript10310^{-3} to 103superscript10310^{3}, and a logarithmic scale is employed on the y-axis to enhance observation. It can be noted from Figure 3 that SROA consistently achieves the lowest objective values across different λ𝜆\lambda values, with the exception of the FDMA scheme when λ=10𝜆10\lambda=10. Additionally, by examining the enlarged subfigures, it can be observed that the interval between adjacent tick marks is 50000 in Fig.3(a) and 2500 in Fig.3(b), respectively. Although the curves of SROA and HFEL appear visually close to each other, the objective value of SROA is significantly lower than that of HFEL. This observation further demonstrates the superiority of SROA over HFEL and FEDL in terms of achieving lower objective values.

VI-C Results of user assignment methods

In this section, we evaluate the performance of the proposed user assignment algorithms. The experimental parameters are set as follows: Dn∈[150,220]subscript𝐷𝑛150220D_{n}\in[150,220], s=881​KB𝑠881KBs=881\ \text{KB}, λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1, and I=80𝐼80I=80. We compare the performance of TSIA with two baseline methods, namely HFEL [35] and JUARA [39]. HFEL adopts a random generation approach for the initial user assignment pattern and utilizes device transferring adjustment and device exchanging adjustment techniques. As HFEL requires a long execution time to reach convergence, we set the numbers of device transferring adjustment and device exchanging adjustment iterations to 100 and 300, respectively. JUARA addresses the user assignment problem by leveraging Lagrangian relaxation and derives the user assignment pattern using Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions, given a large enough time delay. Next, JUARA iteratively reduces the time delay value by a fixed step until it becomes smaller than the lower bound of the time delay. In our experiments, the total number of assigning iterations for JUARA is set to 100, with the step length adjusted accordingly. For both TSIA and HFEL, we assign an importance weight of λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1.

Fig. 4 provides the objective values (15) under different user assignment methods. For the FDMA scheme, the time delay Tsumsubscript𝑇sumT_{\text{sum}} is higher in TSIA than in HFEL. However, TSIA effectively reduces the energy consumption Esumsubscript𝐸sumE_{\text{sum}} of the HFL system, leading to a lower overall objective value. This improvement is attributed to TSIA’s ability to transfer users from costly servers to economic servers, thereby achieving a balanced workload distribution. In contrast, HFEL relies on random adjustments, making it challenging to achieve an optimal assignment pattern, particularly in large search spaces. For the OFDMA scheme, TSIA outperforms JUARA in terms of both time delay and energy consumption. JUARA does not optimize the CPU frequency and average transmit power of mobile users, and it also fails to consider the energy consumption associated with training or transmitting HFL models. Therefore, TSIA proves advantageous by considering these factors and achieving superior results in terms of minimizing time delay and energy consumption.

We now provide an elaboration on the convergence behavior of TSIA, as depicted in Fig.5. As discussed in SectionV, TSIA achieves convergence when it revisits a previously encountered user assignment pattern. For instance, in Fig. 5(a), the assignment pattern at the 13th assigning iteration matches that of the 11th iteration, indicating the convergence of TSIA. Furthermore, we investigate the relationship between the convergence rate of TSIA and the number of assigning iterations, as influenced by the quantities of mobile users (N𝑁N) and edge servers (M𝑀M). In Fig.6(a), we fix M𝑀M at 5 and vary N𝑁N from 10 to 100. Similarly, in Fig.6(b), N𝑁N is fixed at 50 while M𝑀M ranges from 2 to 10. The results reveal that TSIA requires a greater number of assigning iterations to achieve convergence when the count of mobile users or edge servers increases. Additionally, for N=50𝑁50N=50 and M=5𝑀5M=5, the number of assigning iterations typically falls within the range of 20 to 50. In comparison, JUARA and HFEL utilize 100 and 400 assigning iterations, respectively. This observation indicates that TSIA shows a considerably faster convergence speed compared with HFEL111For TSIA, HFEL, and JUARA, an assigning iteration corresponds to a single execution of the spectrum resource management methods. Hence, the convergence speed of TSIA, HFEL, and JUARA can be evaluated based on the number of assigning iterations..

VI-D Comparison between HFL and traditional FL

The proposed HFL framework is compared with traditional FL. Both HFL and traditional FL are trained using the same mobile users, allowing for a direct comparison of the learning performance. The numbers of local update L𝐿L and edge aggregation K𝐾K in HFL are both 5. The number of local update in FL LFLsubscript𝐿FLL_{\text{FL}} is 5. The experiments are repeated five times. Fig. 7 presents the learning accuracy of the testing set throughout the training process. The accuracy curves of HFL and FL exhibit proximity, indicating that the learning performance of HFL is comparable to that of traditional FL. This finding suggests that transferring a portion of the model aggregation to the edge does not result in a deterioration of learning performance.

Additionally, we evaluate the objective value (15) Esum+λ​Tsumsubscript𝐸sum𝜆subscript𝑇sumE_{\text{sum}}+\lambda T_{\text{sum}} of both HFL and FL, with λ=1𝜆1\lambda=1. The experiments are conducted five times, with variations in the locations of the mobile users and edge servers, as well as the values of Dnsubscript𝐷𝑛D_{n} and cnsubscript𝑐𝑛c_{n}. The cloud server remains fixed at the centre of the area. In FL, the mobile users solely communicate with the cloud server, and the bandwidth resource of this cloud server, denoted as BFLsubscript𝐵FLB_{\text{FL}}, corresponds to the summation of the bandwidth resources of all the edge servers in HFL (i.e., ∑m=1MBmsuperscriptsubscript𝑚1𝑀subscript𝐵𝑚\sum_{m=1}^{M}B_{m}). Figure 8 presents the experimental results for both the FDMA and OFDMA schemes. It can be seen that the objective value (15) in HFL is always lower compared with traditional FL. This observation indicates that the communication and computation overheads are alleviated through the involvement of the edge servers. In summary, the proposed HFL framework enables the system to achieve lower system costs while maintaining learning performance compared with the traditional FL framework.

VII Conclusions

Hierarchical Federated Learning (HFL) has been proposed to address privacy concerns and relieve network congestion in FL. In this paper, we have studied the mechanism of HFL over wireless networks and investigated the user assignment problem in HFL. We formulated a user assignment problem to minimize the weights sum of the latency and energy consumption of HFL. To solve this problem, we proposed a two-stage iterative algorithm (TSIA) to handle the user assignment problem. TSIA iteratively transfers the mobile users from the straggler server to other servers, thus alleviating the communication and computation overheads of all the edge servers. As user assignment couples with the resource allocation problem, we proposed a spectrum resource optimization algorithm (SROA) to jointly optimize users’ bandwidth, CPU frequency, and average transmit power within a single edge server. The experimental results showed that SROA outperforms other benchmarks in minimizing energy consumption and time delay of HFL. Besides, TSIA enables HFL to significantly reduce global costs with a faster convergence speed. Finally, compared with traditional FL, HFL achieves a lower global cost while ensuring learning performance.

Replacing x𝑥x with bnsubscript𝑏𝑛b_{n}, the lower bound of N0hn​y​(bn)subscript𝑁0subscriptℎ𝑛𝑦subscript𝑏𝑛\frac{N_{0}}{h_{n}}y(b_{n}) is obtained when bn=bmaxsubscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑏maxb_{n}=b_{\text{max}}.

In terms of pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} and fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}, (32) is rewritten as follows.

pnsubscript𝑝𝑛\displaystyle p_{n} ≥2Ynt−δn−Jnfn−1Znabsentsuperscript2subscript𝑌𝑛𝑡subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝐽𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛1subscript𝑍𝑛\displaystyle\geq\frac{2^{\frac{Y_{n}}{t-\delta_{n}-\frac{J_{n}}{f_{n}}}}-1}{Z_{n}} (40)

When fn>0subscript𝑓𝑛0f_{n}>0, t−δn−Jnfn𝑡subscript𝛿𝑛subscript𝐽𝑛subscript𝑓𝑛t-\delta_{n}-\frac{J_{n}}{f_{n}} is an increasing function w.r.t. fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}. Therefore, the lefthand side of (40) is a decreasing function w.r.t. fnsubscript𝑓𝑛f_{n}. In this case, the lower bound of pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} is obtained when fn=fnmaxsubscript𝑓𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓max𝑛f_{n}=f^{\text{max}}_{n}.

In conclusion, the lower bound of pnsubscript𝑝𝑛p_{n} is achieved when bn=bmaxsubscript𝑏𝑛subscript𝑏maxb_{n}=b_{\text{max}} and fn=fnmaxsubscript𝑓𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑓max𝑛f_{n}=f^{\text{max}}_{n}. ∎
